PostValue.explanation: A practical, well‑curated roundup that’s useful for people working on farmed animal advocacy and for EA funders/interested community members — helps with fundraising, capacity building, networking and signals momentum in the cause. It’s not making foundational theoretical claims and wouldn’t substantially shift global priorities on its own, so it’s moderately important within the movement but of minor direct importance to general humanity.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) No stated selection methodology or prioritisation — the post is a very long list of links but doesn’t say how or why particular resources were chosen, which makes it hard for readers to know what to prioritise. Actionable fix: add a short paragraph that explains your inclusion criteria (timeframe, source types, relevance thresholds), and highlight a small “Top 5–10” or “Must-read” set for different audiences (e.g. fundraisers, regional organisers, researchers). This keeps the post compact while steering busy readers to the highest-value items.

2) Potential conflict-of-interest / self-promotion is under-disclosed — Hive appears frequently in the list and in the narrative, but there’s no explicit disclosure of your organisational role or how much of the roundup is sourced from your own newsletter/community. Actionable fix: add a 1–2 sentence disclosure about Hive’s involvement (e.g. “These resources were curated from our Hive Highlights newsletter and Hive community submissions”) and, where you include Hive items, mark them clearly (e.g. “(Hive resource)”). Consider balancing with a note on how you verified external resources or sought independent recommendations.

3) Lack of synthesis or short annotations — nearly every item is a bare link; readers don’t get quick signals about why each resource matters (quality, scope, who it’s for). Actionable fix: add a one-line annotation for each item or at least for the top recommendations and new initiatives (e.g. “what it contains / why it’s useful / intended audience”). If space is a concern, collapse lower-priority links into a downloadable appendix or a single ‘full list’ link and keep the main post focused on annotated highlights.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: Strong, actionable feedback that targets the post’s two biggest weaknesses for readers: lack of curation criteria/prioritisation and absence of quick syntheses/annotations. Adding a short inclusion-methods blurb and a ‘Top 5–10 / must-read’ for key audiences would substantially increase trust and usability with little extra length. The COI point is valid but slightly overstated—the post already signals Hive authorship/newsletter origin, so it mainly needs a brief explicit disclosure/labeling of Hive-sourced items rather than a major rewrite. Overall, implementing these suggestions would meaningfully improve the post without large length costs.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: I don’t recognize 'Hive' as a notable author or pseudonym within the EA/rationalist community or more broadly as of my 2024-06 knowledge cutoff. No well-known publications, frequent forum posts, or public appearances under that single-name handle are identifiable. If you mean a specific person/account (link or context), I can reassess.

PostClarity.explanation: Well-structured and highly comprehensible: clear TL;DR, logical themes, headings and extensive curated links make the purpose and content obvious. Weaknesses are its length and very high link density (which can overwhelm skimmers), occasional minor typos/redundancies, and limited high-level synthesis — a short executive summary or priority call-outs would improve conciseness and scannability.

PostNovelty.explanation: This is primarily a curated roundup and link collection rather than an original argument or theory. For EA Forum readers (longtermists/animal-advocacy insiders) most themes (funding shortages, capacity building, alt-protein momentum) and many of the cited reports/threads will already be familiar, so novelty is low. The only modestly new elements are the specific 2024 updates — new funds, org launches, Hive’s own metrics and events — which are newsworthy but not conceptually original. For the general public the aggregation of many sector-specific resources and launches is somewhat more novel (news they’re unlikely to have seen compiled), but still not highly original.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: The post is well-structured and coherent (clear themes, organized resource lists) and backs key claims (e.g., funding is a major challenge) with links to reputable surveys and movement signals (Faunalytics, AASF survey, ACE, 80,000 Hours, EA Donation Election). It provides many concrete examples and primary sources. Weaknesses: Most of the piece is a curated compilation rather than an argument with causal inference or rigorous synthesis; many claims are phrased as impressions (“we’ve seen”, “we’re excited”) and rely on selective examples and self-reported indicators (conference attendance, Slack growth). Empirical evidence is broad and relevant but uneven in depth — there are many links but limited aggregation, counterevidence, or quantitative impact analysis to demonstrate the magnitude of the asserted trends. Potential selection and self-promotion biases are not addressed.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most major, load‑bearing claims in the roundup are verifiable and well supported by primary sources: Faunalytics and Rethink Priorities both report funding is a top constraint for advocates; 80,000 Hours did move factory farming onto its list of “most pressing” problems; the 2024 EA Forum Donation Election winners and Farmed Animal Funders’ Aquatic Animal Funding Circle are documented; the Bezos Earth Fund Future of Food / Bezos Centers announcements and Denmark’s DKK 15bn green research commitment are confirmed. Hive’s organisational metrics and fundraising totals are self‑reported on their site (so verifiable as Hive’s claims). Two numeric claims are the weakest/least transparent: (a) the post’s statement that Faunalytics’ study found funding was “cited as an obstacle by 95% of respondents” — Faunalytics’ public summary strongly emphasizes funding as the top barrier but I could not find a clear 95% figure in the summary (it may be in the full report/data tables); and (b) the “5.5% of effective giving in 2023” figure appears in community analyses and forum posts based on compiled EA grants data, but its value depends on scope/definitions (which funds/grants are included) and so is not an unambiguous official statistic. Overall, the piece is well supported and mostly accurate, with a few precise numbers that need clearer provenance or caveats.
sources: Faunalytics — "Pathways To Impact: An International Study Of Advocates’ Strategies And Needs" (May 29, 2024) — Faunalytics summary and download page. (faunalytics.org/pathways-to-impact).
Rethink Priorities — "2024 Animal Advocacy Strategy Forum: Event summary and survey results" (rethinkpriorities.org/research-area/2024-aasf-summary).

80,000 Hours — "Updates to our problem rankings..." and the Factory Farming problem profile (80000hours.org/2024/10/updates-to-our-problem-rankings-on-factory-farming-climate-change-and-more/; 80000hours.org/problem-profiles/factory-farming/).

Bezos Earth Fund — Press release: "Lauren Sánchez Announces $60 Million to Establish Bezos Centers for Sustainable Protein" and Future of Food program pages (bezosearthfund.org/news-and-insights/lauren-sanchez-announces-60-million-establish-bezos-centers-for-sustainable-protein; bezosearthfund.org/our-programs/future-of-food).
Vegconomist / Danish government reporting — "Danish Government Allocates DKK 15Bn to Green Research and Innovation" (vegconomist.com article reporting DKK 15bn commitment).
Animal Charity Evaluators (ACE) — "Movement Grants: Announcing The Round 8 Recipients" (animalcharityevaluators.org/blog/announcing-2024-movement-grants-recipients).

Farmed Animal Funders — "Aquatic Animal Funding Circle" (farmedanimalfunders.org/articles/the-aquatic-animal-funding-circle) and EA Forum post cross‑posting (forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/u9yzGEkyrB6ZeSr6J/funder-opportunity-aquatic-animal-funding-circle).

Hive — "Resources for Farmed Animal Advocacy: 2024 Roundup" (primary post being evaluated) and Hive site metrics pages (joinhive.org/updates/resources-for-farmed-animal-advocacy-2024-roundup; joinhive.org/slack).

EA Funds / community analyses — Animal Welfare Fund payout reports and forum posts with EA funding breakdowns (funds.effectivealtruism.org/payouts and community forum posts summarising EA funding shares used to derive the ~5.5% figure).
